sen.j: 栄典（えいてん）は、国家や公共に対する功労者を表彰するために、国家が与える待遇・地位・称号などの総称。
sen.e: Eiten (honor) is the generic term for the treatment, position and title that the nation gave as a commendation to a person who has rendered distinguished service to the nation and the public.
Eiten (honor) is a generic term for treatment, positions and titles that the nation gives as a commendation to a person who has rendered distinguished service to the nation and the public.
sen.cmt: gaveを givesに変更、その他表現の見直ししました。
sen.e: Eiten (honor) is a generic term for treatment, positions and titles that the nation gives as a commendation to a person who has rendered distinguished service to the nation and the public.

sen.j: また、その制度。
sen.e: Eiten also refers to its system.
Eiten also refers to its system.
Eiten also refers to its system.

sen.j: 多くの場合名誉が国家に認定され表彰される形をとるが、中世に於ける位階や爵位等の様に特権や特別待遇がそれに附随する場合もある。
sen.e: Usually, a commendation is given to a person when his/her honor is certified by the nation, and in some cases, privileges and special treatment are appertained, like Ikai (Court rank) or peerage of the medieval period.

Usually, a commendation is given to a person when his/her honor is certified by the nation, and in some cases, privileges and special treatment appertain to the commendation, like Ikai (Court rank) or peerage of the medieval period.
sen.cmt: are appertained をappertain to the commendation に変更（appertainは自動詞）しました。
sen.e: Usually, a commendation is given to a person when his/her honor is certified by the nation, and in some cases, privileges and special treatment appertain to the commendation, like Ikai (Court rank) or peerage of the medieval period.

sen.j: 国家間の外交儀礼では勲章・爵位の有無や等級等により席順が変わっていた。
sen.e: At a diplomatic ceremony between nations, the seat arrangement was determined depending on whether the person has a decoration or a peerage, and what grade he/she was.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: At a diplomatic ceremony between nations, the seat arrangement was determined depending on whether the person has a decoration or a peerage, and what grade he/she was at.
At a diplomatic ceremony between nations, the seat arrangement was determined depending on whether the person has a decoration or a peerage, and what grade he/she was at.

sen.j: 戦前の日本では宮中席次として10階級79種が定められていた。
sen.e: In Japan before the war, 10 ranks and 79 kinds were set as the in-palace seat ranks which was defined in the Imperial Ceremony Ordinance.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In Japan before the Second World War, 10 ranks and 79 kinds were set as in-palace seat ranks defined in the Imperial Ceremony Ordinance.
sen.cmt: the war --> the Second World War
sen.e: In Japan before the Second World War, 10 ranks and 79 kinds were set as in-palace seat ranks defined in the Imperial Ceremony Ordinance.

sen.j: 日本の近代に於ける栄典制度は主に位階・勲章・爵位が挙げられるが、他に麝香間祗候・錦鶏間祗候や宮中顧問官のように特別な官職につく例や元老と称される元勲優遇、内閣総理大臣・枢密院議長を経験した者になされる前官礼遇の様に待遇に関する物、勲章に準ずる賜杯（賞杯）、特に功績のあった臣下に賜る勅語・国葬が挙げられる。
sen.e: Japanese Eiten system in modern times mainly included Ikai, decorations and peerages, but in some cases, it also included the following: special posts, such as Jako no ma shiko (emperor's personal attendant in the Jako room), Kinkei-no-ma shiko (Kinkei Hall attendant) and an imperial court councilor; the preference to veteran statesmen called Genro (elder statesman); the courteous reception of the previous post given to a person who used to be a prime minister or a Chairman of the Privy Council; an Emperor's cup (prize cup) based on a decoration; and the imperial rescript and the state funeral for a minister who especially had a great achievement.

Japanese Eiten system in modern times mainly included Ikai, decorations and peerages, but in some cases, it also included the following: special posts, such as Jako no ma shiko (emperor's personal attendant in the Jako room), Kinkei-no-ma shiko (Kinkei Hall attendant) and an imperial court councilor; the preference to veteran statesmen called Genro (elder statesman); the courteous reception of the previous post given to a person who used to be a prime minister or a Chairman of the Privy Council; an Emperor's cup (prize cup) based on a decoration; and the imperial rescript and the state funeral for a minister who especially had a great achievement.

Japanese Eiten system in modern times mainly included Ikai, decorations and peerages, but in some cases, it also included the following: special posts, such as Jako no ma shiko (emperor's personal attendant in the Jako room), Kinkei-no-ma shiko (Kinkei Hall attendant) and an imperial court councilor; the preference to veteran statesmen called Genro (elder statesman); the courteous reception of the previous post given to a person who used to be a prime minister or a Chairman of the Privy Council; an Emperor's cup (prize cup) based on a decoration; and the imperial rescript and the state funeral for a minister who especially had a great achievement.

sen.j: 栄典の授与は天皇の重要な権限であり、これらは何れも天皇が与える形式をとっている。
sen.e: The conferment of Eiten was one of the important authorities of the Emperor, and all Eitan were conferred by the Emperor as a formality..
The conferment of Eiten was one of the important authorities of the Emperor, and all Eitan were conferred by the Emperor as a formality..
The conferment of Eiten was one of the important authorities of the Emperor, and all Eitan were conferred by the Emperor as a formality..

sen.j: 勲記に天皇の名も表示されない勲八等の様に下位のものであっても『賜る』と表現している。
sen.e: Even the lower rank like Kun hachito (the 8th Order of Merit) whose Kunki (decoration diploma) does not have the name of the Emperor on it, was described to be "conferred by the Emperor".
sen.cmt: 「勲記」を「Kunki (decoration diploma)」と訳しました。「勲八等」を「Kun hachito (the 8th Order of Merit)」と訳しました。
sen.e: Even the lower rank like Kun hachito (the 8th Order of Merit) whose Kunki (decoration diploma) does not have the name of the Emperor in it, was described to be "conferred by the Emperor."
sen.cmt: the name of the Emperor on it の onを in に変更、ピリオドを引用符の内側に収容しました。
sen.e: Even the lower rank like Kun hachito (the 8th Order of Merit) whose Kunki (decoration diploma) does not have the name of the Emperor in it, was described to be "conferred by the Emperor."

sen.j: 大日本帝国憲法では天皇大権の一つで栄典大権といい、日本国憲法でも国事行為の一つと規定している。
sen.e: The Constitution of the Empire of Japan stipulates this Emperor's sovereign authority to award honors as one of the Emperor's powers, while the Constitution of Japan also stipulates it as one of the Emperor's constitutional functions.

The Constitution of the Empire of Japan stipulates this Emperor's sovereign authority to award honors as one of the Emperor's powers, while the Constitution of Japan also stipulates it as one of the Emperor's constitutional functions.

The Constitution of the Empire of Japan stipulates this Emperor's sovereign authority to award honors as one of the Emperor's powers, while the Constitution of Japan also stipulates it as one of the Emperor's constitutional functions.

sen.j: また、天皇は関わらないものの1977年（昭和52年）に制定された国民栄誉賞や内閣総理大臣顕彰等も栄典の一種と言える。
sen.e: Although the Emperor was not involved, the People's Honor Award and the Prime Minister's Award established in 1977 are also considered as one of Eiten.
Although the Emperor is not involved, the People's Honor Award and the Prime Minister's Award established in 1977 are also considered as one of Eiten.
Although the Emperor is not involved, the People's Honor Award and the Prime Minister's Award established in 1977 are also considered as one of Eiten.

sen.j: 変遷
sen.e: Change
Change
Change

sen.j: 日本の勲章制度は1875年（明治8年）4月10日に賞牌従軍牌制定ノ件（太政官布告第54号）が制定されたのに始まる。
sen.e: The decoration system in Japan was started when 賞牌従軍牌制定ノ件 (the establishment of the prize-medal and war-medal system)(Dajokan fukoku [the proclamation by the Grand Council of State] No.54)was established on April 10, 1875.
sen.cmt: 「賞牌従軍牌制定ノ件（しょうはいじゅうぐんはいせいていのけん？）」については、読み方不明です。「制定された」のではなく、「公布された」のではないかと思いましたが、そのまま「established」と訳しました。
sen.e: The decoration system in Japan was started when 賞牌従軍牌制定ノ件 (the establishment of the prize-medal and war-medal system)(Dajokan fukoku [the proclamation by the Grand Council of State] No.54)was established on April 10, 1875.

The decoration system in Japan was started when 賞牌従軍牌制定ノ件 (the establishment of the prize-medal and war-medal system)(Dajokan fukoku [the proclamation by the Grand Council of State] No.54)was established on April 10, 1875.

sen.j: この時制定された勲章が今日の旭日章の元となる。
sen.e: The decoration established at that time became the base of the current Kyokujitsusho (The Order of the Rising Sun).
The decoration established at that time became the base of the current Kyokujitsusho (The Order of the Rising Sun).
The decoration established at that time became the base of the current Kyokujitsusho (The Order of the Rising Sun).

sen.j: 1876年（明治9年）には菊花章が制定さる。
sen.e: The Order of the Chrysanthemum was established in 1876.
The Order of the Chrysanthemum was established in 1876.
The Order of the Chrysanthemum was established in 1876.

sen.j: 1881年（明治14年）12月褒章条例（明治14年太政官布告第63号）の公布により紅綬褒章、緑綬褒章、藍綬褒章が制定され褒章の授与が始まる。
sen.e: Due to the Ordinance of Medals (Dajokan fukoku No. 63) issued in December 1881, the Medal with Red Ribbon, the Medal with Green Ribbon and the Medal with Blue Ribbon were established, and the conferment of medals was started.

In the Ordinance of Medals (Dajokan fukoku No. 63) issued in December 1881, the Medal with Red Ribbon, the Medal with Green Ribbon and the Medal with Blue Ribbon were established, and the conferment of medals was started.

In the Ordinance of Medals (Dajokan fukoku No. 63) issued in December 1881, the Medal with Red Ribbon, the Medal with Green Ribbon and the Medal with Blue Ribbon were established, and the conferment of medals was started.

sen.j: 1888年（明治21年）瑞宝章・宝冠章が制定される。
sen.e: In 1888, the Order of the Sacred Treasure and the Orders of the Precious Crown were established.
In 1888, the Order of the Sacred Treasure and the Orders of the Precious Crown were established.
In 1888, the Order of the Sacred Treasure and the Orders of the Precious Crown were established.

sen.j: 1890年（明治23年）には軍人専用の勲章である金鵄勲章が制定された。
sen.e: In 1890, the decoration only for military personnel, Kinshi kunsho (the Order of the Golden Kite) was established.
In 1890, the decoration only for military personnel, Kinshi kunsho (the Order of the Golden Kite) was established.
In 1890, the decoration only for military personnel, Kinshi kunsho (the Order of the Golden Kite) was established.

sen.j: 以後も褒章の種類が追加される。
sen.e: Afterward, more kinds of medals were added.
Afterward, more kinds of medals were added.
Afterward, more kinds of medals were added.

sen.j: 1937年（昭和12年）には文化勲章の授与が始まった。
sen.e: In 1937, the conferment of Bunka Kunsho (the Order of Culture) was started.
In 1937, the conferment of Bunka Kunsho (the Order of Culture) was started.
In 1937, the conferment of Bunka Kunsho (the Order of Culture) was started.

sen.j: 終戦に伴い生存者の叙勲は停止されていたが、1964年（昭和39年）に叙勲を復活させた。
sen.e: With the end of war, the bestowal of an order for survivors was suspended, but was resumed in 1964.
With the end of World War II, the bestowal of an order for survivors was once suspended, but was resumed in 1964.
sen.cmt: warをWorld War IIに変更、onceを追加しました。
sen.e: With the end of World War II, the bestowal of an order for survivors was once suspended, but was resumed in 1964.

sen.j: 2003年（平成15年）には勲章制度が全面的に改正され、数字による等級を廃止し叙勲基準も見直した。
sen.e: When the decoration system was thoroughly revised in 2003, the grading with number was abolished and the decoration standard was also reviewed.
When the decoration system was thoroughly revised in 2003, the grading with number was abolished and the decoration standard was also reviewed.
When the decoration system was thoroughly revised in 2003, the grading with number was abolished and the decoration standard was also reviewed.

sen.j: また、このときの議論で勲章と重複した制度であると批判があった褒章の廃止も検討されたが、据え置かれた。
sen.e: During this discussion, the abolishment of the medal system, which had been criticized for overlapping with the decoration system, was considered but postponed.
During this discussion, the abolishment of the medal system, which had been criticized for overlapping with the decoration system, was considered but postponed.
During this discussion, the abolishment of the medal system, which had been criticized for overlapping with the decoration system, was considered but postponed.

sen.j: 表示
sen.e: Display
Display
Display

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦前の日本は階級社会であったことはよく知られているが、身分をあらわす為に位階勲等を並べて表示した。
sen.e: It is well-known that Japan was a class society before the World War II, and the ranks and orders were indicated next to each other.
It is well-known that Japan was a class society before the World War II, and the ranks and orders were indicated next to each other.
It is well-known that Japan was a class society before the World War II, and the ranks and orders were indicated next to each other.

sen.j: 公文書に於いて身分を表示する場合は以下のような規則に基づいた。
sen.e: A social status was indicated in the formal document according to the following rules.
The social status was indicated in formal documents according to the following rules.
sen.cmt: A social status を The social statusに, in the formal document を in formal documentsに変更しました。
sen.e: The social status was indicated in formal documents according to the following rules.

sen.j: この方式は、国会における国会議員等物故時の弔詞において今なお踏襲されている。
sen.e: This system is still used now in a memorial address given at the time of a Diet member's death.
This system is still used today in a memorial address given at the time of a Diet member's death and the like.
sen.cmt: nowをtodayに変更、and the like を追加しました。
sen.e: This system is still used today in a memorial address given at the time of a Diet member's death and the like.

sen.j: 表示順
sen.e: Display Order
Display Order
Display Order

sen.j: 補職
sen.e: Position
sen.cmt: ここでの「補職」を「職業」と解釈し、「position」としました。
sen.e: Position
Position

sen.j: 階級（陸軍大将・海軍大将のように軍における階級）
sen.e: Class (the class in military, such as Army General and Full Admiral)
Rank (ranks in military, such as Army General and Full Admiral)
Rank (ranks in military, such as Army General and Full Admiral)

sen.j: 位階
sen.e: Ikai (the court rank)
Ikai (the court rank)
Ikai (the court rank)

sen.j: 勲等
sen.e: Kunto (the order of merit)
Kunto (the order of merit)
Kunto (the order of merit)

sen.j: 功級（金鵄勲章の等級の事）
sen.e: Kinshi kunsho (the ranks of the Orders of the Golden Kite)
Kokyu (ranks of the Orders of the Golden Kite)
Kokyu (ranks of the Orders of the Golden Kite)

sen.j: 爵位
sen.e: Peerage
Peerage

sen.e: Doctorate

sen.j: 表示例

Display Example

sen.j: 内閣総理大臣元帥陸軍大将従一位大勲位功一級公爵医学博士 日本太郎
sen.e: Prime Minister, Marshal Army General, Junior First Rank, Supreme Order, First Class, Prince, Doctor of Medicine, Taro NIPPON.
Prime Minister, Marshal Army General, Junior First Rank, Supreme Order, First Class, Prince, Doctor of Medicine, Taro NIPPON.
Prime Minister, Marshal Army General, Junior First Rank, Supreme Order, First Class, Prince, Doctor of Medicine, Taro NIPPON.

sen.j: 補職は官吏としての役職しか表示しない。
sen.e: Only an official post was indicated as a position.
Only an official post was indicated as a position.
Only an official post was indicated as a position.

sen.j: 元帥陸軍大将の内、元帥は階級名ではなく称号だが、陸軍大将の前に冠して表示した。
sen.e: Marshal' in 'Marshal Army General' was not a class name but a title, however, it was written in front of 'Army General'.
The term 'Marshal' in 'Marshal Army General' was not a rank name but a title, however, it was written in front of 'Army General.'
sen.cmt: 表現の見直ししました。
sen.e: The term 'Marshal' in 'Marshal Army General' was not a rank name but a title, however, it was written in front of 'Army General.'

sen.j: 例では従一位としたが、位階における最高位は正一位。
sen.e: Juichii (Junior First Rank) is indicated in the example, but the highest Ikai is Shoichii (Senior First Rank).
Juichii (Junior First Rank) is indicated in the example, but the highest Ikai is Shoichii (Senior First Rank).
Juichii (Junior First Rank) is indicated in the example, but the highest Ikai is Shoichii (Senior First Rank).

sen.j: 但し存命中は正一位になれない（死後、追贈されることはある）。
sen.e: However, Shoichii was not conferred to anyone alive (but was conferred posthumously).
However, Shoichii was not conferred to anyone alive (but was conferred posthumously).
However, Shoichii was not conferred to anyone alive (but was conferred posthumously).

sen.j: 勲等では最高位が大勲位、最下位が勲八等である。
sen.e: The highest order of Kunto was the Supreme Order, and its lowest order was Kun hachito (the Eighth Order).
The highest order of Kunto was the Supreme Order, and its lowest order was Kun hachito (the Eighth Order).
The highest order of Kunto was the Supreme Order, and its lowest order was Kun hachito (the Eighth Order).

sen.j: 勲等勲章としては大勲位菊花大綬章や勲一等旭日大綬章という様に勲章の部分もあるが、勲章の名称はこの場合表示しない。
sen.e: In this case, the decoration names in the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum and the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun are not indicated.
sen.cmt: 「大勲位菊花大綬章や勲一等旭日大綬章などの勲章の名称はこの場合表示しない。」と解釈して訳しました。
sen.e: The Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum and the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun include each order of decoration in their names, however, the order of decoration is not indicated in these cases.
sen.cmt: 表現の見直ししました。
sen.e: The Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum and the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun include each order of decoration in their names, however, the order of decoration is not indicated in these cases.

sen.j: 金鵄勲章は軍人・軍属にのみ与えられたのもの。
sen.e: Kinshi kunsho was conferred exclusively on the military or the civilian workers for the military.
Kinshi kunsho was conferred exclusively on the military or the civilian workers for the military.
Kinshi kunsho was conferred exclusively on the military or the civilian workers for the military.

sen.j: 学位は表示しないこともある。
sen.e: An academic degree is not always indicated.
An academic degree is not always indicated.
An academic degree is not always indicated.

sen.j: 功級、爵位が廃止となった日本国憲法下の国会にあっても、博士号を除く残余の部分は国会議員等への弔詞に用いられる。
sen.e: In the Diet under the Constitution of Japan where the Orders of the Golden Kite and peerages have been abolished, the rest of the ranks and orders excluding doctorate is still used in the memorial address for a Diet member.

In the Diet under the Constitution of Japan where the Orders of the Golden Kite and peerages have been abolished, the rest of the ranks and orders excluding doctorates are still used in the memorial address for a Diet member.
sen.cmt: doctorate --> doctorates,is still used --> are still used
sen.e: In the Diet under the Constitution of Japan where the Orders of the Golden Kite and peerages have been abolished, the rest of the ranks and orders excluding doctorates are still used in the memorial address for a Diet member.

sen.j: この場合、「元内閣総理大臣」のように元職が用いられたり、官吏の補職ではないが政党の役職（総裁など最高位のものに限る）が冠される例がある。
sen.e: In this instance, a former position such as 'the former Prime Minister', or a position in a political party (only the highest positions such as a president) other than an official position, was indicated in some cases.

In this case, a former position such as 'former Prime Minister', or a position in a political party (only the highest position such as the president) other than official positions, is indicated sometime.
sen.cmt: 表現の見直ししました。
sen.e: In this case, a former position such as 'former Prime Minister', or a position in a political party (only the highest position such as the president) other than official positions, is indicated sometime.

sen.j: 2003年（平成15年）11月3日以降の新制度下で数字表記の勲等のない勲章を授与された者について弔詞を贈る場合は、旧制度時代の「勲等のみで勲章は省略」という原則によらず「正三位旭日大綬章」のように位階に続けて勲章を表示する。
sen.e: When a memorial address is given for a person who was conferred a decoration without a numerically-notated Kunto (the order of merit) under the new system after November 3, 2003, the general rule of the old system, 'Only Kunto, no decoration', is not applied, and a decoration is indicated after Ikai like 'Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank), Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun'.

When a memorial address is given for a person who was conferred a decoration on without a numerical-notation Kunto (the order of merit) under the new system after November 3, 2003, the general rule of the old system, i.e., 'Only Kunto, no decoration', is not applied, and a decoration is indicated after Ikai like 'Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) as follows: Senior Third Rank Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun.'
sen.cmt: 表現の見直ししました。
sen.e: When a memorial address is given for a person who was conferred a decoration on without a numerical-notation Kunto (the order of merit) under the new system after November 3, 2003, the general rule of the old system, i.e., 'Only Kunto, no decoration', is not applied, and a decoration is indicated after Ikai like 'Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) as follows: Senior Third Rank Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun.'

sen.j: 皇族（三后を除く）の場合
sen.e: The Imperial family (excluding Sanko [the Grand Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager and the Empress Consort])
The Imperial family (excluding Sanko [the Grand Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager and the Empress Consort])
The Imperial family (excluding Sanko [the Grand Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager and the Empress Consort])

sen.j: 大勲位○仁親王、勲一等○子内親王、勲二等○子女王
sen.e: The Supreme Order, Imperial Prince -hito; The First Order of Merit, Imperial Princess -shi; The Order of the Second Class, Princess -shi/ko
sen.cmt: 名前の入る「○」の部分を英訳では「-」と表記しました。
sen.e: The Supreme Order, Imperial Prince -hito; The First Order of Merit, Imperial Princess -shi; The Order of the Second Class, Princess -shi/ko
The Supreme Order, Imperial Prince -hito; The First Order of Merit, Imperial Princess -shi; The Order of the Second Class, Princess -shi/ko

sen.j: ○仁親王妃勲一等○子
sen.e: The wife of Imperial Prince -hito, the First Order of Merit, -shi/ko
sen.cmt: 名前の入る「○」の部分を英訳では「-」と表記しました。
sen.e: The wife of Imperial Prince -hito, the First Order of Merit, -shi/ko
The wife of Imperial Prince -hito, the First Order of Merit, -shi/ko

sen.j: 歌会始での表示（1959年まで）、皇族の墓碑銘などで勲等を明示する場合は、いずれも本人の名の前に冠する（親王妃及び王妃にあっては夫たる皇族の名の前には冠さない）。
sen.e: When Kunto is indicated at the New Year Imperial Poetry Reading Party (until 1959) or in the epitaph of Imperial Family, it is put in front of the person's own name (in the case of an Imperial Prince and a Princess, their Kunto was not put in front of the name of their husband, Imperial Family).

When indicating Kunto at the New Year Imperial Poetry Reading Party (until 1959) or in the epitaph of Imperial Family, it is put in front of the person's own name (in the case of an Imperial Prince and a Princess, their Kunto is not put in front of the name of their husband, Imperial Family).
sen.cmt: 表現の見直ししました。
sen.e: When indicating Kunto at the New Year Imperial Poetry Reading Party (until 1959) or in the epitaph of Imperial Family, it is put in front of the person's own name (in the case of an Imperial Prince and a Princess, their Kunto is not put in front of the name of their husband, Imperial Family).
